   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 36 M with end stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, with
   trach in [**Hospital1 169**]; now admit with hypotension and positive blood and sputum
   cultures.
 HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK)
   Per [**Hospital1 630**] his baseline bp appears to be mid 90s, had one BP of 84/52
   on [**8-2**] but [**Name8 (MD) **] RN supervisor appears to have been in the 90s since.
   Believes sent in more for low grade temps (up to 100.8 off and on); in
   ED had SBP 90 and has been in the 90's to 100's since.  Has advanced
   HIV but no recent CD4 count (none since prior to HAART) so therefore
   may be at high risk for infection.  Also with indwelling line x unclear
   time period.
   - Blood and urine cultures pending.
   - Resent sputum culture, though no evidence of infiltrate on CXR
   (unlikely to treat based on likely colonization).
   - Vanco and zosyn for GNR coverage for now while awaiting cultures.
   - 2 c.diffs negative in last ~week; follow up third to r/o.
   - Further workup for sepsis can be tailored based on CD4 count
   (pending).
   - Consider workup/treatment coverage for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] nothing on CXR and
   oxygenation good (and has been on ppx).
   - LP likely low yield, will reconsider if w/u negative
   - If appearing septic; goal direceted therapy with fluid boluses,
   pressors to keep MAP >65, Aline placement, [**Last Name (un) 45**] stim.
   - Keep PICC for now, will readdress following cx results; keep femoral
   line for now but if CVL needed for few days can change to IJ/SC.
   - Consider non-infectious causes of hypotension (ROMI,
   bleed/hypovolemia).
   - Will give low dose beta block for now, increase as BP tolerates back
   to home dose.
   # Bacteremia.  Last positive culture several weeks ago; was on vanco in
   past but course appears completed.  Has L PICC, unclear how old.
   - f/u cultures as above
   - Coverage with vanco.
   - HD monitoring as above.
   - Will keep lines in pending cx results, given chronic course of
   current illness.
   # Positive sputum cultures. No clear evidence of pneumonia on CXR, but
   with significant immunosuppresion.
   - Will continue zosyn for now.
   - can check sputum cultures, but unclear if treatment warranted given
   lack of infiltrate.
   - cont home colistin.
 .H/O FEVER (HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA, NOT FEVER OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN)
   - Temp to 100.4 Axillary, workup as above
   - Acetaminophen as needed for fever
 .H/O AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   - Pt s/p trach, copious secretion, and baseline colonization.
   - CXR am of [**8-8**]
 TACHYCARDIA, OTHER
   Sinus.  Likely long standing (though unclear etiology) given [**Name (NI) 169**] dosing
   of 400 mg metoprolol daily.
   - give low dose BB for now, being careful to avoid exacerbating
   hypotension.
   - received 3+ Liters NS boluses, with good response in BP, but HR
   continues to be 100-120
 HIV (HUMAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRUS, ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY
   SYNDROME, AIDS)
   Last CD4 count 17 was prior to HAART; now on HAART x 4 months.
   - Recheck CD4
   - Continue HAART.
   - Continue atovaquone for prophylaxis.
   - Mefloquine
 [**Last Name 121**] PROBLEM - ENTER DESCRIPTION IN COMMENTS
   Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
   Very poor mental status at baseline, does not appear changed per
   [**Hospital1 630**] reports.  Progressive neurologic impairment as expected.
   - Consider head CT/LP for workup of fever as above, though does not
   appear that mental status worsening- will hold off for now.
   - Goals of care discussion with mother when able
 ANEMIA, CHRONIC
   Macrocytic likely [**2-2**] HAART.  No change in last week.  Will continue to
   monitor.
   # History of EtOH abuse.  Now at skilled nursing, no concern for
   withdrawal issues.
   # FEN. Tube feeds, nutrition consult in for regimen similar to that at
   [**Hospital1 **]
   # PPx: HSQ, H2 blocker.
   # Access: R femoral TLC.  L sided PICC.
   # Communication.  Mother [**Name (NI) 249**] is HCP; number is [**Telephone/Fax (1) 3958**];
   unable to reach on [**2137-8-6**].
   # Dispo.  ICU pending stability of BP, treatment of ?infection.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Replete with Fiber (Full) - [**2137-8-7**] 01:55 AM 40 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2137-8-6**] 09:36 PM
   PICC Line - [**2137-8-6**] 09:38 PM
   Comments: Will leave PICC in place overnight, pending cx results.
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Mother is contact, reportedly only answers
   phone after 10 AM

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 36-year-old male with end-stage HIV/AIDS and known progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). The patient was admitted to the ICU with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.1°C (100.5°F)
* Heart rate: 118 bpm
* Blood pressure: 100/51 mmHg (63/57 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 26 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 100%

The patient has a history of HIV and has been on HAART for 4 months. The patient has also had a positive CD4 count of 17 prior to HAART, which suggests that the patient may be at high risk for infection.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 4.2 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 250 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dL
* TropT: <0.01
* Glucose: 106 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination shows:

* General appearance: Well-nourished, no acute distress
* Cardiovascular: Normal sinus rhythm, no murmurs or gallops
* Respiratory: Normal lung sounds, no wheezing or rhonchi
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present
* Extremities: No cyanosis or clubbing
* Skin: Warm, no rash
* Neurologic: No meningismus, no focal neurologic deficits

The patient's medical history includes:

* HIV/AIDS
* PML
* Indwelling line (PICC) placed unclear time period
* History of EtOH abuse
* FEN tube feeds
* Nutrition consult for regimen similar to that at [**Hospital1 **]
* PPx: HSQ, H2 blocker

The patient's medications include:

* HAART
* Atovaquone
* Mefloquine
* Colistin
* Acetaminophen
* K+ SS
* Mag SS
* Famotidine
* Heparin
* Metoprolol
* Scopolamine patch

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is 100/51 mmHg, which is considered hypotensive. The patient is being treated with vasopressors and fluid boluses to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 65 mmHg.
* Bacteremia: The patient has positive blood and sputum cultures, which suggests bacteremia. The patient is being treated with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam.
* Sepsis: The patient's temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), which is above normal. The patient is being treated with acetaminophen and fluid boluses.
* Anemia: The patient has a hemoglobin level of 8.7 g/dL, which is considered anemia. The patient is being monitored and will continue to receive blood transfusions as needed.
* Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy: The patient has a history of PML, which is a complication of HIV/AIDS. The patient's mental status is poor, and the patient is being monitored for any changes.
* Airway management: The patient has a tracheostomy and is receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's airway is being monitored for any changes.

The potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Sepsis: The patient's positive blood and sputum cultures suggest bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis.
* Anemia: The patient's low hemoglobin level can lead to anemia, which can cause fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
* Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy: The patient's history of PML can lead to progressive neurologic impairment, which can cause confusion, disorientation, and memory loss.
* Airway management: The patient's tracheostomy and mechanical ventilation can lead to airway complications, such as pneumonia, tracheitis, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
* Fluid overload: The patient's fluid boluses and vasopressors can lead to fluid overload, which can cause edema, hypertension, and cardiac failure.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for infection and sepsis due to his positive blood and sputum cultures, and his history of HIV/AIDS and PML. The patient's anemia and airway management are also concerns. The patient's potential medical complications include sepsis, anemia, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, airway management, and fluid overload.

   HIV but no recent CD4 count (none since prior to HAART) so therefore
   may be at high risk for infection.  Also with indwelling line x unclear
   time period.
   - Blood and urine cultures pending.
   - Resent sputum culture, though no evidence of infiltrate on CXR
   (unlikely to treat based on likely colonization).
   - Vanco and zosyn for GNR coverage for now while awaiting cultures.

   (pending).

   - LP likely low yield, will reconsider if w/u negative

   line for now but if CVL needed for few days can change to IJ/SC.
   - Consider non-infectious causes of hypotension (ROMI,
   bleed/hypovolemia).
   - Will give low dose beta block for now, increase as BP tolerates back
   to home dose.
   # Bacteremia.  Last positive culture several weeks ago; was on vanco in
   past but course appears completed.  Has L PICC, unclear how old.
   - f/u cultures as above
   - Coverage with vanco.
   - HD monitoring as above.
   - Will keep lines in pending cx results, given chronic course of
   current illness.

   with significant immunosuppresion.

   - can check sputum cultures, but unclear if treatment warranted given

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient's blood and sputum cultures are pending, but they have a history of PML and are immunocompromised, making them at high risk for sepsis.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is consistently in the 90s, and they have received multiple liters of normal saline boluses to maintain blood pressure. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of hypotension.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient has a tracheostomy and is on oxygen therapy, but their respiratory status is unstable, and they require close monitoring.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level has dropped from 24.9 to 22.5, and they have received a transfusion of packed red blood cells. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of anemia.
5. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML): The patient has a history of PML, and their mental status is poor. Further evaluation is needed to determine the progression of the disease.
6. HIV/AIDS: The patient has a history of HIV/AIDS and is on antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Further evaluation is needed to determine the effectiveness of HAART and the patient's CD4 count.
7. Fever of unknown origin: The patient's temperature has been elevated, and no clear source has been identified. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of the fever.
8. Potential for aspiration: The patient has a tracheostomy and is at risk for aspiration due to their altered gag reflex and copious secretions.
9. Potential for septic shock: The patient's blood pressure is consistently in the 90s, and they have received multiple liters of normal saline boluses to maintain blood pressure. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of hypotension and the risk of septic shock.

The patient's current medications include:

* Vancomycin for gram-positive coverage
* Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) for gram-negative coverage
* Famotidine (Pepcid) for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Heparin sodium for prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis
* Acetaminophen for fever control
* Atovaquone for prophylaxis against Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia
* Mefloquine for prophylaxis against malaria
* HAART for HIV/AIDS treatment

The patient's lab results show:

* White blood cell count: 4.2
* Hemoglobin: 24.8
* Platelet count: 187
* CD4 count: 53
* Creatinine: 0.6
* Troponin-T: <0.01
* Glucose: 106
* Lipase: 20
* Amylase: 21
* Albumin: 2.6
* LDH: 209 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.7 mg/dL

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.6°F
* Heart rate: 100-120 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 90-100 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 21 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Unresponsive, does not appear agitated
* Skin: no rash
* HEENT: tracheostomy, copious secretions, moist mucous membranes
* Chest: coarse/ronchorous breath sounds
* Heart: regular rate and rhythm
* Abdomen: soft, non-tender, positive bowel sounds
* Extremities: 2-3+ edema in both lower extremities
* Neuro: unresponsive, eyes open spontaneously

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Temperature: 101.6°F (38.7°C)
* Blood pressure: 90/48 mmHg
* Heart rate: 100-120 bpm
* Respiratory rate: 21 breaths/min
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* White blood cell count: 4.2 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 187 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Glucose: 106 mg/dL

The patient has been diagnosed with bacteremia, positive sputum cultures, and suspected sepsis. He is being treated with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam for GNR coverage, and further workup is pending.

The patient has a history of chronic anemia, which is likely macrocytic due to HAART. He has also been prescribed HAART for the past four months.

The patient's neurological status is poor, and he has progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy. He is being monitored for any changes in his mental status.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is pending further workup.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Sepsis and septic shock
* Pneumonia
* Bacteremia and endocarditis
* Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
* Chronic anemia
* Hypotension and shock
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Neurological deterioration

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these complications and improve his outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a fever of 101.6°F (38.7°C) and hypotension (blood pressure of 90/48 mmHg). The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 100 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient has a history of allergies to dapsone, abdominal pain, and antibiotic use. The patient's laboratory results show anemia, chronic, with a hemoglobin level of 8.5 g/dL and a white blood cell count of 4.2 K/uL. The patient's medical history includes chronic anemia and antibiotic use.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and hypotension may indicate sepsis, which can lead to organ failure and death if not treated promptly.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea (rapid breathing rate) and hypoxemia (low oxygen saturation) may indicate respiratory failure, which can lead to respiratory arrest and death.
3. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypotension and tachycardia may indicate cardiovascular instability, which can lead to cardiac arrest and death.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of abdominal pain and antibiotic use may indicate gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and death.
5. Infection: The patient's fever and white blood cell count may indicate infection, which can lead to sepsis and death if not treated promptly.
6. Kidney damage: The patient's elevated creatinine level may indicate kidney damage, which can lead to chronic kidney disease and death if not treated promptly.
7. Liver damage: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may indicate liver damage, which can lead to liver failure and death if not treated promptly.
8. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's abnormal electrolyte levels may indicate an electrolyte imbalance, which can lead to muscle weakness, cardiac arrhythmias, and death if not treated promptly.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and medical history to identify any potential complications and provide prompt treatment to prevent further deterioration of the patient's condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-inch tall individual weighing 85.5 kg, who is currently admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of fever. The patient has a history of allergies to Dapsone, Abdominal pain, and Bactrim DS.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.6°F (38.7°C)
* Heart rate: 100 bpm (87-120 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 90/48 mmHg (58-103/68 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 21 inspirations per minute (12-26 inspirations per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient has received various medications, including Vancomycin, Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn), Famotidine (Pepcid), and Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis).

The patient's lab results show:

* White blood cell count: 4.2 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 187 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01
* Glucose: 106 mg/dL
* Other lab results: see below

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the patient's inability to respond or move. The patient's skin, peripheral vascular, and neurologic examinations were not assessed.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypotension (not in shock)
* Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin)
* Airway, inability to protect (risk for aspiration, altered gag, airway clearance, cough)
* Tachycardia, other
* Anemia, chronic

The patient is at risk for potential medical complications, including:

* Aspiration pneumonia due to the patient's inability to protect their airway
* Sepsis due to the patient's fever and hypotension
* Respiratory failure due to the patient's tachypnea and hypoxemia
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to the patient's tachycardia
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to the patient's anemia and chronic bleeding disorder
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to the patient's immobility and risk factors
* Stress ulcer due to the patient's critical illness and risk factors
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to the patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation
* Infection due to the patient's fever and risk factors

Based on the patient's condition and risk factors, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, lab results, and physical examination findings to identify any potential complications and adjust the patient's treatment plan accordingly.

   Assessment and Plan
   36 M with end stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, with trach in [**Hospital1 169**]; now admit
   with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures.
 HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK)
   Per [**Hospital1 630**] his baseline bp appears to be mid 90s, had one BP of 84/52
   on [**8-2**] but [**Name8 (MD) **] RN supervisor appears to have been in the 90s since.
   Believes sent in more for low grade temps (up to 100.8 off and on); in
   ED had SBP 90 and has been in the 90's to 100's since.  Has advanced
   HIV but no recent CD4 count (none since prior to HAART) so therefore
   may be at high risk for infection.  Also with indwelling line x unclear
   time period.
   - Blood and urine cultures pending.
   - Resent sputum culture, though no evidence of infiltrate on CXR
   (unlikely to treat based on likely colonization).
   - Vanco and zosyn for GNR coverage for now while awaiting cultures.
   - 2 c.diffs negative in last ~week; follow up third to r/o.
   - Further workup for sepsis can be tailored based on CD4 count
   (pending).
   - Consider workup/treatment coverage for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] nothing on CXR and
   oxygenation good (and has been on ppx).
   - LP likely low yield, will reconsider if w/u negative
   - If appearing septic; goal direceted therapy with fluid boluses,
   pressors to keep MAP >65, Aline placement, [**Last Name (un) 45**] stim.
   - Keep PICC for now, will readdress following cx results; keep femoral
   line for now but if CVL needed for few days can change to IJ/SC.
   - Consider non-infectious causes of hypotension (ROMI,
   bleed/hypovolemia).
   - Will give low dose beta block for now, increase as BP tolerates back
   to home dose.
   # Bacteremia.  Last positive culture several weeks ago; was on vanco in
   past but course appears completed.  Has L PICC, unclear how old.
   - f/u cultures as above
   - Coverage with vanco.
   - HD monitoring as above.
   - Will keep lines in pending cx results, given chronic course of
   current illness.
   # Positive sputum cultures. No clear evidence of pneumonia on CXR, but
   with significant immunosuppresion.
   - Will continue zosyn for now.
   - can check sputum cultures, but unclear if treatment warranted given
   lack of infiltrate.
   - hold colistin as not available in inhaled form
 .H/O FEVER (HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA, NOT FEVER OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN)
   - Temp to 101.6 as above
   - Cx sputum, blood, stool, urine
   - H/o multiple pulmonary infections with multiple resistance, no other
   clear source
   - Continue vancomycin
   - Acetaminophen as needed for fever
   - discussion with mother regarding goals of care
 .H/O AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   - Pt s/p trach, copious secretion, and baseline colonization.
   - CXR am of [**8-8**]
 TACHYCARDIA, OTHER
   Sinus.  Likely long standing (though unclear etiology) given [**Name (NI) 169**] dosing
   of 400 mg metoprolol daily.
   - give low dose BB for now, being careful to avoid exacerbating
   hypotension.
   - received 3+ Liters NS boluses, with good response in BP, but HR
   continues to be 100-120
 HIV (HUMAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRUS, ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY
   SYNDROME, AIDS)
   Last CD4 count 17 was prior to HAART; now on HAART x 4 months.
   - Recheck CD4
   - Continue HAART.
   - Continue atovaquone for prophylaxis.
   - Mefloquine
 [**Last Name 121**] PROBLEM - ENTER DESCRIPTION IN COMMENTS
   Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
   Very poor mental status at baseline, does not appear changed per
   [**Hospital1 630**] reports.  Progressive neurologic impairment as expected.
   - Consider head CT/LP for workup of fever as above, though does not
   appear that mental status worsening- will hold off for now.
   - Goals of care discussion with mother today
 ANEMIA, CHRONIC
   Macrocytic likely [**2-2**] HAART.  No change in last week.   Pt had Hct drop
   to 22.5 yesterday from 28.5 on admission.  Pt transfused 1 unit packed
   RBCs, Hct up to 24.8.
   -          Guiac stools
   -          Repeat hct 1500
   -          Further w/u following results
   # History of EtOH abuse.  Now at skilled nursing, no concern for
   withdrawal issues.
   ICU Care

The patient's potential medical complications include:

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with end-stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, and a tracheostomy. He was admitted to the ICU with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures. His baseline blood pressure is reportedly in the mid-90s, but has been in the 90s to 100s since admission. He has advanced HIV with no recent CD4 count, making him at high risk for infection.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.4°C (97.5°F)
* Heart rate: 101 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 99/61 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 inspirations per minute (insp/min)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: MAP >65 mmHg

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Genital: unresponsive, appears in normal alert and responsive state (NAD)
* Head, eyes, ears, nose, and throat (HEENT): tracheostomy in place, copious secretions, eyes open
* Chest: ronchorous breath sounds bilaterally
* Cardiovascular (CV): regular rate and rhythm (RRR)
* Abdomen (Abd): soft, non-tender (ND)
* Extremities (Ext): bl upper extremity (UE) mildly edematous, trace edema bl lower extremity (LE)
* Skin: warm and dry
* Neuro/Psych: unresponsive to verbal stimuli

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 4.2
* Hematocrit (Hct): 25.5
* Platelet count (Plt): 200,000/μL
* Creatinine (Cr): 0.5 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01
* Glucose: 106 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 14.3/28.6/1.2, CK/CKMB: 21/<0.01, ALT/AST: 35/32, Alk Phos/T Bili: 78/0.4, Amylase/Lipase: 24/22, Albumin: 2.7 g/dL, LDH: 233 IU/L, Ca++: 8.3 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.0 mg/dL, PO4: 3.3 mg/dL

Imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): lungs grossly clear, possible small left pleural effusion, heart size at upper end of normal range.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's condition and treatment include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood and sputum cultures, along with his hypotension and tachycardia, suggest the possibility of sepsis.
2. Pneumonia: Despite the patient's negative sputum culture, his history of multiple pulmonary infections and immunosuppression make pneumonia a potential complication.
3. Anemia: The patient's chronic anemia, likely related to his HIV/AIDS and HAART therapy, may worsen if not properly managed.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension, despite fluid resuscitation and vasopressor support, may persist and require further management.
5. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia, likely related to his sepsis and hypotension, may worsen if not properly managed.
6. Neurological deterioration: The patient's progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) may worsen, leading to neurological deterioration.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate, requiring mechanical ventilation.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to address these potential complications and provide appropriate management.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a chief complaint of abdominal pain. They have a history of allergies to dapsone and Bactrim DS. They received antibiotics, including Piperacillin/Tazobactam and Vancomycin, and are currently receiving Heparin Sodium for prophylaxis and Famotidine for stress ulcer prophylaxis. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a Tmax of 37.8°C, Tcurrent of 36.4°C, HR of 101 bpm, BP of 99/61 mmHg, RR of 14 inspirations per minute, and SpO2 of 100%. They are receiving oxygen therapy via a tracheal mask and have a stable respiratory status.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.1 g/dL, and thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 200 K/uL. Their liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an AST of 32 IU/L and an ALT of 35 IU/L. Their electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level of 5.6 mEq/L.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their inability to assess certain areas, including their peripheral vascular, skin, and neurologic systems. They are at risk for aspiration due to their inability to protect their airway.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's history of abdominal pain and antibiotics, there is a risk of sepsis developing.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachycardia and altered mental status may indicate respiratory failure or impending respiratory failure.
3. Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and anemia make them at risk for bleeding, particularly with invasive procedures.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine level of 0.6 mg/dL suggests potential renal impairment.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may indicate cardiovascular instability, which requires close monitoring and management.
6. Infection: The patient's fever and altered mental status may indicate infection, which requires prompt evaluation and treatment.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's inability to eat and their nutritional status require close monitoring and management to prevent malnutrition.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

   36 M with end stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, with trach in [**Hospital1 169**]; now admit

 HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK)
   Per [**Hospital1 630**] his baseline bp appears to be mid 90s, had one BP of 84/52
   on [**8-2**] but [**Name8 (MD) **] RN supervisor appears to have been in the 90s since.
   Believes sent in more for low grade temps (up to 100.8 off and on); in
   ED had SBP 90 and has been in the 90's to 100's since.  Has advanced
   HIV but no recent CD4 count (none since prior to HAART) so therefore
   may be at high risk for infection.  Also with indwelling line x unclear
   time period.
   - Afebrile overnight, continue to monitor
   - Blood cultures pending.
   - Sputum showed no growth, though no evidence of infiltrate on CXR
   (unlikely to treat based on likely colonization).
   - Urine showed no growth
   - D/c antibiotics today as has been afebrile with no identifiable
   source.
   - 2 c.diffs negative in last ~week; follow up third to r/o- also
   negative.
   - Further workup for sepsis can be tailored based on CD4 count (53).
   - Consider workup/treatment coverage for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] nothing on CXR and
   oxygenation good (and has been on ppx).
   - Keep PICC for now, will readdress following cx results
   - Per outside hospital records, had been on 25 Metoprolol [**Hospital1 **]; the 100
   mg QID listed by [**Hospital1 630**] is a large increase.  Will titrate down to
   Metoprolol 37.5 mg TID today.
   - Follow CXR and clinical signs
   # Bacteremia.  Last positive culture several weeks ago; was on vanco in
   past but course appears completed.  Has L PICC, unclear how old.
   - Afebrile overnight
   - f/u cultures as above
   - Coverage with vanco.
   - HD monitoring as above.
   - Will keep PICC in for now
   # H/o Positive sputum cultures. No clear evidence of pneumonia on CXR,
   but with significant immunosuppresion.
   - Sputum showed no microorganisms
   - Will continue zosyn for now.
   - hold colistin as not available in inhaled form
 .H/O FEVER (HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA, NOT FEVER OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN)
   - Temp to 101.6 previously, but afebrile overnight
   - Cx sputum, blood, stool, urine results as above, follow up other cx
   - H/o multiple pulmonary infections with multiple resistance, no other
   clear source
   - Continue vancomycin
   - Acetaminophen as needed for fever
 .H/O AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   - Pt s/p trach, copious secretion, and baseline colonization.
   - follow CXR
 TACHYCARDIA, OTHER
   Sinus.  Likely long standing (though unclear etiology) given [**Name (NI) 169**] dosing
   of 400 mg metoprolol daily.
   - continue 50 mg Metoprolol TID
   - Monitor for hypotension
   - HR continues to be 90-115
 HIV (HUMAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRUS, ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY

   - CD4 on recheck
   - Continue HAART.
   - Continue atovaquone for prophylaxis.

   Metoprolol 37.5 mg TID today.
   - Follow CXR and clinical signs

   past but course appears completed.  Has L PICC, unclear how old.

His blood cultures are pending, and he has been discontinued from antibiotics as he has been afebrile with no identifiable source of infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

3. Bacteremia: The patient's positive blood cultures suggest the possibility of bacteremia. Further workup and treatment are needed to address this potential complication.
4. HIV-related infections: The patient's advanced HIV disease and immunosuppression make him at high risk for opportunistic infections. Further workup and treatment are needed to address this potential complication.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's PML and poor mental status make him at high risk for neurological complications. Further workup and treatment are needed to address this potential complication.
6. Anemia: The patient's chronic anemia and recent transfusion suggest the possibility of ongoing bleeding or blood loss. Further workup and treatment are needed to address this potential complication.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's low platelet count suggests the possibility of bleeding or blood loss. Further workup and treatment are needed to address this potential complication.
8. Fluid imbalance: The patient's fluid balance suggests the possibility of dehydration or fluid overload. Further workup and treatment are needed to address this potential complication.
9. Respiratory complications: The patient's tracheostomy and copious secretions suggest the possibility of respiratory complications. Further workup and treatment are needed to address this potential complication.
10. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension suggest the possibility of cardiac complications. Further workup and treatment are needed to address this potential complication.

Summary:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with end-stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, and tracheostomy in a different facility. He was admitted to the ICU with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures. His baseline blood pressure is in the mid-90s, and he has a history of low-grade temperatures. He is at high risk for infection due to his advanced HIV and lack of recent CD4 count. He has an indwelling line of unclear duration and is being treated with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for Gram-negative rod coverage.

The patient's lab results show anemia, chronic macrocytic likely due to HAART. He has a history of ethanol abuse and is currently in a skilled nursing facility with no concern for withdrawal issues.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.7°C (99.8°F)
* Heart rate: 96 bpm (89-114)
* Blood pressure: 92/62 mmHg (69-111/77)
* Respiratory rate: 20 inspirations per minute (11-25)
* SpO2: 99%

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has positive blood and sputum cultures, which increases the risk of sepsis.
2. Bacteremia: The patient has a history of positive sputum cultures and is at risk for bacteremia.
3. Pneumonia: The patient has a history of multiple pulmonary infections and is at risk for pneumonia.
4. Neurological impairment: The patient has progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, which can lead to neurological impairment.
5. Anemia: The patient has chronic macrocytic anemia, which can lead to fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
6. Hypotension: The patient has hypotension, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient has a tracheostomy and is at risk for respiratory failure.
8. Cardiovascular instability: The patient has a history of tachycardia and is at risk for cardiovascular instability.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and lab results closely.
2. Continue treatment with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for Gram-negative rod coverage.
3. Consider further workup for sepsis, including blood cultures and imaging studies.
4. Consider treatment for PML, including antiviral therapy and corticosteroids.
5. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusions if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and consider treatment for hypotension if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider intubation if necessary.
8. Consider treatment for cardiovascular instability, including beta blockers and vasopressors if necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a multi-lumen femoral line inserted. The patient has a history of abdominal pain and allergies to Dapsone and Bactrim DS. They have been receiving antibiotics, including Vancomycin and Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn), and have been monitored for fluid balance, vital signs, and laboratory results.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1°C (98.7°F), heart rate of 96 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 92/62 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen therapy through a tracheal mask and have a SpO2 of 99%. The patient's respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation, and their ABG results show a pH of 7.30, PCO2 of 30 mmHg, and PO2 of 60 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 4.2 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.2 g/dL, and platelet count of 193 K/uL. Their electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a potassium level of 4.2 mEq/L, sodium level of 136 mEq/L, and chloride level of 101 mEq/L. Their blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 25.5 mg/dL, and their creatinine level is 0.5 mg/dL.

The patient has a history of fever, tachycardia, and altered mental status, which may be related to their underlying condition. They are at risk for aspiration, altered gag reflex, and airway clearance due to their inability to protect their airway. The patient's ICU care includes nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's fever, tachycardia, and altered mental status, they may be at risk for sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Aspiration: The patient's inability to protect their airway puts them at risk for aspiration, which could lead to pneumonia, respiratory failure, and cardiac arrest.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's risk for DVT is increased due to their immobility and the presence of central lines. This could lead to pulmonary embolism and subsequent respiratory and cardiovascular complications.
4. Stress ulcer: The patient's risk for stress ulcer is increased due to their critical illness and the use of corticosteroids. This could lead to gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation.
5. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's use of mechanical ventilation increases their risk for VAP, which could lead to respiratory failure and sepsis.
6. Renal failure: The patient's elevated BUN and creatinine levels suggest potential kidney dysfunction. This could lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and end-stage renal disease.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may be indicative of underlying cardiac disease. This could lead to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac arrest.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and the potential complications that may arise, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of their ICU care.

   36 M with end stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, with trach in [**Hospital1 169**]; now admit
   with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures.
 HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK)
   Per [**Hospital1 630**] his baseline bp appears to be mid 90s, had one BP of 84/52
   on [**8-2**] but [**Name8 (MD) **] RN supervisor appears to have been in the 90s since.
   Believes sent in more for low grade temps (up to 100.8 off and on); in
   ED had SBP 90 and has been in the 90's to 100's since.  Has advanced
   HIV but no recent CD4 count (none since prior to HAART) so therefore
   may be at high risk for infection.  Also with indwelling line x unclear
   time period.
   - Afebrile overnight, continue to monitor
   - Blood cultures pending.
   - Sputum showed no growth, though no evidence of infiltrate on CXR
   (unlikely to treat based on likely colonization).
   - Urine showed no growth
   - D/c antibiotics today as has been afebrile with no identifiable
   source.
   - 2 c.diffs negative in last ~week; follow up third to r/o- also
   negative.
   - Further workup for sepsis can be tailored based on CD4 count (53).
   - Consider workup/treatment coverage for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] nothing on CXR and
   oxygenation good (and has been on ppx).
   - Keep PICC for now, will readdress following cx results
   - Per outside hospital records, had been on 25 Metoprolol [**Hospital1 **]; the 100
   mg QID listed by [**Hospital1 630**] is a large increase.  Will titrate down to
   Metoprolol 37.5 mg TID today.
   - Follow CXR and clinical signs
   # Bacteremia.  Last positive culture several weeks ago; was on vanco in
   past but course appears completed.  Has L PICC, unclear how old.
   - Afebrile overnight
   - f/u cultures as above
   - Will keep PICC in for now
   # H/o Positive sputum cultures. No clear evidence of pneumonia on CXR,
   but with significant immunosuppresion.
   - Sputum showed no microorganisms
   - hold colistin as not available in inhaled form
 .H/O FEVER (HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA, NOT FEVER OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN)
   - Temp to 101.6 previously, but afebrile overnight
   - Cx sputum, blood, stool, urine results as above, follow up other cx
   - H/o multiple pulmonary infections with multiple resistance, no other
   clear source
   - Acetaminophen as needed for fever
 .H/O AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   - Pt s/p trach, copious secretion, and baseline colonization.
   - CXR has been stable, no need to monitor daily
 TACHYCARDIA, OTHER
   Sinus.  Likely long standing (though unclear etiology) given [**Name (NI) 169**] dosing
   of 400 mg metoprolol daily.
   - Decrease to 37.5 mg Metoprolol TID
   - Monitor for hypotension
   - HR continues to be 90-115
 HIV (HUMAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRUS, ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY
   SYNDROME, AIDS)
   Last CD4 count 17 was prior to HAART; now on HAART x 4 months.
   - CD4 on recheck
   - Continue HAART.
   - Continue atovaquone for prophylaxis.
 [**Last Name 121**] PROBLEM - ENTER DESCRIPTION IN COMMENTS
   Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
   Very poor mental status at baseline, does not appear changed per
   [**Hospital1 630**] reports.  Progressive neurologic impairment as expected.
   - Consider head CT/LP for workup of fever as above, though does not
   appear that mental status worsening- will hold off for now.
   - Goals of care discussion with mother yesterday- would not want him
   intubated, would not want chest compressions- code status changed to
   DNR/DNI.

 ANEMIA, CHRONIC
   Macrocytic likely [**2-2**] HAART.  No change in last week.   Pt had Hct drop
   to 22.5 yesterday from 28.5 on admission.  Pt transfused 1 unit packed
   RBCs, Hct up to 24.8.

   -          Hct 24-25
   -          Continue to monitor Hct

   withdrawal issues.

   may be at high risk for infection.  Also with indwelling line x unclear

   - Afebrile overnight, continue to monitor

   (unlikely to treat based on likely colonization).
   - Urine showed no growth
   - D/c antibiotics today as has been afebrile with no identifiable
   source.

   negative.
   - Further workup for sepsis can be tailored based on CD4 count (53).
   - Consider workup/treatment coverage for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] nothing on CXR and
   oxygenation good (and has been on ppx).
   - Keep PICC for now, will readdress following cx results
   - Per outside hospital records, had been on 25 Metoprolol [**Hospital1 **]; the 100
   mg QID listed by [**Hospital1 630**] is a large increase.  Will titrate down to
   Metoprolol 37.5 mg TID today.
   - Follow CXR and clinical signs
   # Bacteremia.  Last positive culture several weeks ago; was on vanco in
   past but course appears completed.  Has L PICC, unclear how old.
   - Afebrile overnight
   - f/u cultures as above
   - Will keep PICC in for now
   # H/o Positive sputum cultures. No clear evidence of pneumonia on CXR,
   but with significant immunosuppresion.
   - Sputum showed no microorganisms
   - hold colistin as not available in inhaled form
 .H/O FEVER (HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA, NOT FEVER OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN)
   - Temp to 101.6 previously, but afebrile overnight
   - Cx sputum, blood, stool, urine results as above, follow up other cx

   - Acetaminophen as needed for fever

Summary:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with end-stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, and tracheostomy. He was admitted to the ICU with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C (99.8°F), heart rate of 96 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 92/62 mmHg. He is receiving antibiotics, and his sputum and blood cultures are pending. He has a history of multiple pulmonary infections with multiple resistance, and his CD4 count is 53. He is on HAART and atovaquone for prophylaxis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood and sputum cultures and hypotension make sepsis a potential complication.
2. Pneumonia: Despite no clear evidence of pneumonia on CXR, the patient's history of multiple pulmonary infections and positive sputum cultures make pneumonia a potential complication.
3. Anemia: The patient's chronic anemia, likely caused by HAART, may worsen due to ongoing blood loss or inadequate transfusion.
4. HIV-related infections: The patient's advanced HIV and immunosuppression make him at high risk for opportunistic infections, such as PCP.
5. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML): The patient's diagnosis of PML is a significant complication, and further neurological deterioration is possible.
6. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen due to his underlying condition, medications, or other factors.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's tracheostomy and copious secretions make respiratory failure a potential complication.
8. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition, likely due to his underlying condition and inadequate nutrition, may worsen his overall health.
9. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of EtOH abuse and chronic anemia make gastrointestinal bleeding a potential complication.
10. Infection-related complications: The patient's multiple infections and immunosuppression make infection-related complications, such as sepsis, pneumonia, and abscesses, a potential risk.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 36-year-old male with a history of HIV, admitted to the ICU for hypotension. The patient's vital signs remain stable, with a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 90 bpm, and blood pressure of 91/53 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an SpO2 of 100% and a respiratory rate of 21 inspirations per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.2 g/dL, and thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 193 K/uL. The patient's renal function is within normal limits, with a creatinine level of 0.5 mg/dL. The patient's liver function is also within normal limits, with an albumin level of 2.7 g/dL and a total bilirubin level of 0.4 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies, including a CXR, show no significant change.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypotension: The patient's hypotension has continued, but it does not appear to have acute worsening over the past 24 hours, which argues against persistent infection.
* HIV: The patient's HIV medications will be continued.
* Airway, inability to protect: The patient's airway is at risk for aspiration, altered gag, airway clearance, and cough.
* ICU care: The patient will continue to receive nutrition via a PICC line, and his glycemic control will be monitored. Prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer will also be continued.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's conditions include:

* Hypotension: Prolonged hypotension can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient is at risk for bleeding complications.
* HIV: The patient is at risk for opportunistic infections and complications related to HIV.
* Airway, inability to protect: The patient is at risk for aspiration, respiratory failure, and other complications related to his airway status.
* ICU care: The patient is at risk for complications related to his ICU care, including catheter-related infections, pressure ulcers, and other issues.

   with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures.
 HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK)
   Per [**Hospital1 630**] his baseline bp appears to be mid 90s, had one BP of 84/52
   on [**8-2**] but [**Name8 (MD) **] RN supervisor appears to have been in the 90s since.
   Believes sent in more for low grade temps (up to 100.8 off and on); in
   ED had SBP 90 and has been in the 90's to 100's since.  Has advanced
   HIV but no recent CD4 count (none since prior to HAART) so therefore
   may be at high risk for infection.  Also with indwelling line x unclear
   time period.
   - Afebrile overnight, continue to monitor
   - Blood cultures pending.
   - Sputum showed no growth, though no evidence of infiltrate on CXR
   (unlikely to treat based on likely colonization).
   - Urine showed no growth
   - D/c antibiotics today as has been afebrile with no identifiable
   source.
   - 2 c.diffs negative in last ~week; follow up third to r/o- also
   negative.
   - Further workup for sepsis can be tailored based on CD4 count (53).
   - Consider workup/treatment coverage for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] nothing on CXR and
   oxygenation good (and has been on ppx).
   - Keep PICC for now, will readdress following cx results
   - Per outside hospital records, had been on 25 Metoprolol [**Hospital1 **]; the 100
   mg QID listed by [**Hospital1 630**] is a large increase.  Will titrate down to
   Metoprolol 37.5 mg TID today.
   - Follow CXR and clinical signs
   # Bacteremia.  Last positive culture several weeks ago; was on vanco in
   past but course appears completed.  Has L PICC, unclear how old.
   - Afebrile overnight
   - f/u cultures as above
   - Will keep PICC in for now
   # H/o Positive sputum cultures. No clear evidence of pneumonia on CXR,
   but with significant immunosuppresion.
   - Sputum showed no microorganisms
   - hold colistin as not available in inhaled form
 .H/O FEVER (HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA, NOT FEVER OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN)
   - Temp to 101.6 previously, but afebrile overnight
   - Cx sputum, blood, stool, urine results as above, follow up other cx
   - H/o multiple pulmonary infections with multiple resistance, no other
   clear source
   - Acetaminophen as needed for fever
 .H/O AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   - Pt s/p trach, copious secretion, and baseline colonization.
   - CXR has been stable, no need to monitor daily
 TACHYCARDIA, OTHER
   Sinus.  Likely long standing (though unclear etiology) given [**Name (NI) 169**] dosing
   of 400 mg metoprolol daily.
   - Decrease to 37.5 mg Metoprolol TID
   - Monitor for hypotension
   - HR continues to be 90-115
 HIV (HUMAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRUS, ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY
   SYNDROME, AIDS)
   Last CD4 count 17 was prior to HAART; now on HAART x 4 months.
   - CD4 on recheck
   - Continue HAART.
   - Continue atovaquone for prophylaxis.
 [**Last Name 121**] PROBLEM - ENTER DESCRIPTION IN COMMENTS
   Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
   Very poor mental status at baseline, does not appear changed per
   [**Hospital1 630**] reports.  Progressive neurologic impairment as expected.
   - Consider head CT/LP for workup of fever as above, though does not
   appear that mental status worsening- will hold off for now.
   - Goals of care discussion with mother yesterday- would not want him
   intubated, would not want chest compressions- code status changed to
   DNR/DNI.

 ANEMIA, CHRONIC
   Macrocytic likely [**2-2**] HAART.  No change in last week.   Pt had Hct drop
   to 22.5 yesterday from 28.5 on admission.  Pt transfused 1 unit packed
   RBCs, Hct up to 24.8.
   -          Guiac stools
   -          Hct 24-25
   -                Continue to monitor Hct
   -
   # History of EtOH abuse.  Now at skilled nursing, no concern for
   withdrawal issues.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren 2.0 (Full) - [**2137-8-9**] 11:50 PM 40 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2137-8-6**] 09:38 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ Heparin
   Stress ulcer:  Famotidine
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR / DNI
   Disposition: In ICU until placed

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 36-year-old male with end-stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, and tracheostomy. He is currently admitted to the ICU with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures.

The patient has a history of multiple pulmonary infections with multiple resistance, and his CD4 count is 53, indicating a high risk for infection. He is on HAART, but his last CD4 count was prior to HAART, and his current CD4 count is unknown.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.2°C (98.9°F) (normal)
* Heart rate: 103 bpm (normal)
* Blood pressure: 94/53 mmHg (hypotensive)
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute (normal)
* Oxygen saturation: 100% (normal)
* Blood glucose: 106 mg/dL (normal)

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* White blood cell count: 4.2 x 10^9/L (normal)
* Hemoglobin: 9.3 g/dL (anemia)
* Platelet count: 234 x 10^9/L (normal)
* Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dL (normal)
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL (normal)
* Glucose: 106 mg/dL (normal)

The patient's medical conditions include:

* HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK): The patient's blood pressure is 94/53 mmHg, which is hypotensive. The patient is at risk for infection due to his advanced HIV and indwelling line.
* BACTEREMIA: The patient has positive blood cultures, and his blood pressure is hypotensive.
* HIV (HUMAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRUS, ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY SYNDROME, AIDS): The patient has advanced HIV/AIDS, and his CD4 count is 53.
* PROGRESSIVE MULTIFOCAL LEUKOENCEPHALOPATHY (PML): The patient has a history of PML, which is a rare complication of HIV/AIDS.
* ANEMIA, CHRONIC: The patient has chronic anemia, likely due to HAART.

The patient's medications include:

* HAART: The patient is on HAART, which is a combination of antiretroviral medications.
* Metoprolol: The patient is taking Metoprolol 100 mg QID, which is a large increase from his previous dose.
* Atovaquone: The patient is taking atovaquone for prophylaxis.
* Famotidine: The patient is taking famotidine for stress ulcer prophylaxis.
* Heparin: The patient is taking heparin for prophylaxis.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Infection: The patient is at high risk for infection due to his advanced HIV and indwelling line.
* Sepsis: The patient has positive blood cultures, and his blood pressure is hypotensive, which increases his risk for sepsis.
* Pneumonia: The patient has positive sputum cultures, and his CXR is stable, but he has a history of multiple pulmonary infections with multiple resistance.
* Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML): The patient has a history of PML, which is a rare complication of HIV/AIDS.
* Anemia: The patient has chronic anemia, which may worsen if his CD4 count decreases.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is hypotensive, which may worsen if his CD4 count decreases.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue HAART and atovaquone for prophylaxis.
* Decrease Metoprolol to 37.5 mg TID.
* Monitor for hypotension and tachycardia.
* Continue to monitor the patient's CD4 count and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.
* Consider a head CT or LP for workup of fever if the patient's mental status worsens.
* Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.
* Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.

   36 M with end stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, with trach in [**Hospital1 169**]; now admit

   oxygenation good (and has been on ppx).

   - Per outside hospital records, had been on 25 Metoprolol [**Hospital1 **]; the 100
   mg QID listed by [**Hospital1 630**] is a large increase.  Will titrate down to
   Metoprolol 37.5 mg TID today.
   - Follow CXR and clinical signs

   - Afebrile overnight

   - Will keep PICC in for now

   - Temp to 101.6 previously, but afebrile overnight
   - Cx sputum, blood, stool, urine results as above, follow up other cx
   - H/o multiple pulmonary infections with multiple resistance, no other
   clear source
   - Acetaminophen as needed for fever
 .H/O AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   - Pt s/p trach, copious secretion, and baseline colonization.
   - CXR has been stable, no need to monitor daily
 TACHYCARDIA, OTHER
   Sinus.  Likely long standing (though unclear etiology) given [**Name (NI) 169**] dosing

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 36-year-old male with end-stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, and tracheostomy. He was admitted to the ICU with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C (98.9°F), heart rate of 103 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 94/53 mmHg. He is receiving oxygen therapy and has a tracheostomy in place.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 234 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 193 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dL
* TropT: <0.01
* Glucose: 106 mg/dL

The patient's medical history is significant for HIV/AIDS, PML, and tracheostomy. He has a history of fever, hypotension, and positive blood and sputum cultures.

The patient's current medications include:

* Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Vancomycin
* Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis)
* Famotidine (Pepcid)

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Afebrile overnight, continue to monitor
* Blood cultures pending
* Sputum showed no growth, though no evidence of infiltrate on CXR (unlikely to treat based on likely colonization)
* Urine showed no growth
* D/c antibiotics today as has been afebrile with no identifiable source
* 2 c.diffs negative in last ~week; follow up third to r/o- also negative
* Further workup for sepsis can be tailored based on CD4 count (53)
* Consider workup/treatment coverage for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] nothing on CXR and oxygenation good (and has been on ppx)
* Keep PICC for now, will readdress following cx results
* Per outside hospital records, had been on 25 Metoprolol [**Hospital1 **]; the 100 mg QID listed by [**Hospital1 630**] is a large increase. Will titrate down to Metoprolol 37.5 mg TID today
* Follow CXR and clinical signs

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

* Sepsis
* Pneumonia
* Bacteremia
* HIV-related complications
* PML progression
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia
* Hypotension
* Fever
* Airway compromise
* Aspiration
* Neurologic impairment

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to identify any potential complications early and intervene promptly to prevent further deterioration.

   HIV but no recent CD4 count (none since prior to HAART) so therefore
   may be at high risk for infection.  Also with indwelling line x unclear
   time period.
   - Afebrile overnight, continue to monitor
   - Blood cultures pending.
   - Sputum showed no growth, though no evidence of infiltrate on CXR
   (unlikely to treat based on likely colonization).
   - Urine showed no growth
   - D/c antibiotics today as has been afebrile with no identifiable
   source.
   - 2 c.diffs negative in last ~week; follow up third to r/o- also
   negative.
   - Further workup for sepsis can be tailored based on CD4 count (53).
   - Consider workup/treatment coverage for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] nothing on CXR and

   - Keep PICC for now, will readdress following cx results
   - Per outside hospital records, had been on 25 Metoprolol [**Hospital1 **]; the 100
   mg QID listed by [**Hospital1 630**] is a large increase.  Will titrate down to
   Metoprolol 37.5 mg TID today.
   - Follow CXR and clinical signs

   past but course appears completed.  Has L PICC, unclear how old.
   - Afebrile overnight
   - f/u cultures as above
   - Will keep PICC in for now
   # H/o Positive sputum cultures. No clear evidence of pneumonia on CXR,
   but with significant immunosuppresion.
   - Sputum showed no microorganisms
   - hold colistin as not available in inhaled form
 .H/O FEVER (HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA, NOT FEVER OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN)
   - Temp to 101.6 previously, but afebrile overnight
   - Cx sputum, blood, stool, urine results as above, follow up other cx

Summary:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with end-stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, and a tracheostomy. He was admitted to the ICU with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 103 bpm, and blood pressure of 94/53 mmHg. He is receiving antibiotics, but they will be discontinued as he has been afebrile with no identifiable source of infection. He has a CD4 count of 53, which may put him at high risk for infection. He is also receiving treatment for PCP prophylaxis and has a PICC line in place.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood cultures and history of PML make him at high risk for sepsis. Close monitoring of his vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of sepsis early.
2. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and history of PML make him at high risk for infection. Close monitoring of his laboratory results and imaging studies is necessary to detect any signs of infection early.
3. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase his risk of bleeding. Close monitoring of his platelet count and bleeding symptoms is necessary.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, which may indicate hypovolemic shock. Close monitoring of his blood pressure and fluid status is necessary to detect any signs of hypovolemic shock early.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's history of PML and progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy make him at high risk for neurological complications. Close monitoring of his neurological status and imaging studies is necessary to detect any signs of neurological complications early.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of tracheostomy and chronic respiratory disease make him at high risk for respiratory failure. Close monitoring of his respiratory status and oxygenation is necessary to detect any signs of respiratory failure early.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of HIV/AIDS and cardiovascular disease make him at high risk for cardiovascular complications. Close monitoring of his cardiovascular status and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of cardiovascular complications early.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 36-year-old male with end-stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, and tracheostomy. He was admitted with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures. The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.2°C (98.9°F) and 35.7°C (96.2°F) over the past 24 hours
* Heart rate: 103 bpm (90-116 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 94/53 mmHg (62-106/74 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 20 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 100%

The patient has a tracheostomy and is receiving oxygen therapy via a tracheal mask. He has a PICC line in place and is receiving IV antibiotics for pseudomonas. His sputum cultures showed sparse growth of pseudomonas, but no evidence of infiltrate on CXR.

The patient has a history of bacteremia, and his blood cultures are pending. He has a CD4 count of 53, which may put him at high risk for infection. He is also at risk for PCP and has been started on Ceftazidime for pseudomonas.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 4.2-3.4 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 234 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.5-0.6 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Glucose: 106-114 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na+: 135 mmol/L, K+: 3.4 mmol/L, Cl-: 100 mmol/L

The patient's physical examination shows:

* General: lying in a neutral position
* Head and neck: moist mucus membranes
* Lungs: coarse breath sounds bilaterally
* Cardiovascular: regular rhythm, no murmurs or gallop
* Abdomen: G-tube in place, normal bowel sounds
* Extremities: no edema, warm to touch
* Peripheral vascular: radial pulses not assessed
* Skin: not assessed
* Neurologic: not alert, no response to pain

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypotension (not shock)
* Bacteremia
* Pseudomonas infection
* HIV/AIDS
* PML
* Anemia (chronic)
* Tachycardia
* Fever (hypothermia)

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue IV antibiotics for pseudomonas
* Monitor blood cultures and sputum cultures
* Continue HAART and prophylaxis for PCP
* Consider workup and treatment for PCP
* Monitor for signs of sepsis
* Continue to monitor vital signs and laboratory results
* Consider head CT/LP for workup of fever
* Hold colistin as not available in inhaled form
* Add nystatin cream for perirectal fungal rash
* Continue to monitor Hct and consider transfusion if necessary
* Consider goals of care discussion with mother regarding code status

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis
* Pneumonia
* Pseudomonas infection
* PCP
* HIV-related opportunistic infections
* Anemia
* Tachycardia
* Hypotension
* Fever
* Neurologic impairment
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and he is expected to be transferred to rehab on Monday.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 36-year-old male with end-stage HIV/AIDS and known PML, admitted to the ICU with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures. He has a history of multiple pulmonary infections with multiple resistance and no clear source. He is currently on HAART and has been for four months.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.2°C (98.9°F)
* Heart rate: 103 bpm (sinus tachycardia)
* Blood pressure: 94/53 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 20 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 100%

The patient has a tracheostomy and is receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a PICC line in place, and his blood cultures are pending.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 4.2 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 234 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01
* Glucose: 106 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* HYPOTENSION (not shock)
* Bacteremia
* H/O Positive sputum cultures
* H/O Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin)
* H/O Airway, inability to protect
* Tachycardia
* HIV/AIDS
* Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
* Anemia, chronic

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Ceftazidime 2g IV q8h for pseudomonas
* Acetaminophen as needed for fever
* Decrease Metoprolol to 37.5 mg TID
* Monitor for hypotension
* Continue HAART
* Continue atovaquone for prophylaxis
* Consider head CT/LP for workup of fever
* Code status changed to DNR/DNI

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis
* Pneumonia
* Bacteremia
* HIV-related complications
* Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
* Anemia
* Hypotension
* Tachycardia
* Airway complications
* Fever
* Inability to protect airway
* HIV-related opportunistic infections

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 36-year-old male admitted to the ICU with hypotension and pneumonia. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 93/56 mmHg, heart rate of 91 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient has a history of allergies to dapsone and Bactrim DS.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, neutrophilia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). The patient's blood cultures are positive for Pseudomonas, and the patient's sputum culture is also positive for Pseudomonas.

The patient's physical examination reveals bilateral crackles in the lung fields, and the patient is receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's abdomen is soft and non-tender.

The patient's medical history is significant for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. The patient is receiving antiretroviral therapy (ART) for HIV and hepatitis B treatment.

The patient's plan of care includes continued antibiotics for Pseudomonas pneumonia, monitoring of blood cultures, and continuation of pulmonary toilet. The patient is also receiving nutrition support with Nutren 2.0.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood cultures and elevated LDH suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's pneumonia and mechanical ventilation increase the risk of respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia and death.
3. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypotension and tachycardia suggest the possibility of cardiovascular instability, which can lead to cardiac arrest and death.
4. Infection-related complications: The patient's positive sputum culture and elevated LDH suggest the possibility of infection-related complications, such as abscesses or empyema.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's malnutrition and need for nutrition support increase the risk of nutritional deficiencies, which can lead to impaired wound healing, increased risk of infection, and death.
6. HIV-related complications: The patient's HIV infection increases the risk of opportunistic infections, such as Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, and AIDS-related complications, such as progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
7. Hepatitis B-related complications: The patient's HBV infection increases the risk of liver failure, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

   Assessment and Plan
   36 M with end stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, with trach in [**Hospital1 169**]; now admit
   with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures.
 HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK)
   Per [**Hospital1 630**] his baseline bp appears to be mid 90s, had one BP of 84/52
   on [**8-2**] but [**Name8 (MD) **] RN supervisor appears to have been in the 90s since.
   Believes sent in more for low grade temps (up to 100.8 off and on); in
   ED had SBP 90 and has been in the 90's to 100's since.  Has advanced
   HIV but no recent CD4 count (none since prior to HAART) so therefore
   may be at high risk for infection.  Also with indwelling line x unclear
   time period.
   - Afebrile overnight, continue to monitor
   - Blood cultures pending.
   - Sputum showed sparse growth of pseduomonas, though no evidence of
   infiltrate on CXR
   - started Ceftazidime 2g IV q8h for pseudomonas
   - Urine showed no growth
   - 2 c.diffs negative in last ~week; follow up third to r/o- also
   negative.
   - Further workup for sepsis can be tailored based on CD4 count (53).
   - Consider workup/treatment coverage for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] nothing on CXR and
   oxygenation good (and has been on ppx).
   - Keep PICC for now, will readdress following cx results
   - Per outside hospital records, had been on 25 Metoprolol [**Hospital1 **]; the 100
   mg QID listed by [**Hospital1 630**] is a large increase.  Titrated down
   Metoprolol  to 37.5 mg TID today.
   - Follow CXR and clinical signs
   # Bacteremia.  Last positive blood culture several weeks ago; was on
   vanco in past but course appears completed.  Has L PICC, unclear how
   old.
   - Ceftaz for pseudomonas in sputum
   - Afebrile overnight
   - f/u cultures as above
   -          Will keep PICC in for now
   - Added nystatin crm for perirectal fungal rash
   # H/o Positive sputum cultures. No clear evidence of pneumonia on CXR,
   but with significant immunosuppresion.
   - Sputum showed no microorganisms
   -          hold colistin as not available in inhaled form
   -          New sputum cult  postivive for pseudomonas, started  Ceftaz
   -          Increased pulmonary secretions as per nursing. On
   scopolamine patch already, added Amitriptyline to decrease secretions
 .H/O FEVER (HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA, NOT FEVER OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN)
   - Temp to 101.6 previously, but afebrile for days
   - Cx sputum, blood, stool, urine results as above, follow up other cx
   - H/o multiple pulmonary infections with multiple resistance, no other
   clear source
   - Acetaminophen as needed for fever
 .H/O AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   - Pt s/p trach, copious secretion, and baseline colonization.
   - added amitripyline to decrease secretions, will titrate up to effect
   reached.
   - CXR has been stable, no need to monitor daily
 TACHYCARDIA, OTHER
   Sinus.  Likely long standing (though unclear etiology) given [**Name (NI) 169**] dosing
   of 400 mg metoprolol daily.
   - Decrease to 37.5 mg Metoprolol TID

   - HR continues to be 90-115
 HIV (HUMAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRUS, ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment and Plan
   36 M with end stage HIV/AIDS, known PML, with trach in [**Hospital1 169**]; now admit
   with hypotension and positive blood and sputum cultures.
 HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK)
   Per [**Hospital1 630**] his baseline bp appears to be mid 90s, had one BP of 84/52
   on [**8-2**] but [**Name8 (MD) **] RN supervisor appears to have been in the 90s since.
   Believes sent in more for low grade temps (up to 100.8 off and on); in
   ED had SBP 90 and has been in the 90's to 100's since.  Has advanced
   HIV but no recent CD4 count (none since prior to HAART) so therefore
   may be at high risk for infection.  Also with indwelling line x unclear
   time period.
   - Afebrile overnight, continue to monitor
   - Blood cultures pending.
   - Sputum showed sparse growth of pseduomonas, though no evidence of
   infiltrate on CXR
   - started Ceftazidime 2g IV q8h for pseudomonas
   - Urine showed no growth
   - 2 c.diffs negative in last ~week; follow up third to r/o- also
   negative.
   - Further workup for sepsis can be tailored based on CD4 count (53).
   - Consider workup/treatment coverage for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] nothing on CXR and
   oxygenation good (and has been on ppx).
   - Keep PICC for now, will readdress following cx results
   - Per outside hospital records, had been on 25 Metoprolol [**Hospital1 **]; the 100
   mg QID listed by [**Hospital1 630**] is a large increase.  Titrated down
   Metoprolol  to 37.5 mg TID today.
   - Follow CXR and clinical signs
   # Bacteremia.  Last positive blood culture several weeks ago; was on
   vanco in past but course appears completed.  Has L PICC, unclear how
   old.
   - Ceftaz for pseudomonas in sputum
   - Afebrile overnight
   - f/u cultures as above
   -          Will keep PICC in for now
   - Added nystatin crm for perirectal fungal rash
   # H/o Positive sputum cultures. No clear evidence of pneumonia on CXR,
   but with significant immunosuppresion.
   - Sputum showed no microorganisms
   -          hold colistin as not available in inhaled form
   -          New sputum cult  postivive for pseudomonas, started  Ceftaz
   -          Increased pulmonary secretions as per nursing. On
   scopolamine patch already, added Amitriptyline to decrease secretions
 .H/O FEVER (HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA, NOT FEVER OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN)
   - Temp to 101.6 previously, but afebrile for days
   - Cx sputum, blood, stool, urine results as above, follow up other cx
   - H/o multiple pulmonary infections with multiple resistance, no other
   clear source
   - Acetaminophen as needed for fever
 .H/O AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   - Pt s/p trach, copious secretion, and baseline colonization.
   - added amitripyline to decrease secretions, will titrate up to effect
   reached.
   - CXR has been stable, no need to monitor daily
 TACHYCARDIA, OTHER
   Sinus.  Likely long standing (though unclear etiology) given [**Name (NI) 169**] dosing
   of 400 mg metoprolol daily.
   - Decrease to 37.5 mg Metoprolol TID
   - Monitor for hypotension
   - HR continues to be 90-115
 HIV (HUMAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRUS, ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY
   SYNDROME, AIDS)
   Last CD4 count 17 was prior to HAART; now on HAART x 4 months.
   - CD4 on recheck
   - Continue HAART.
   - Continue atovaquone for prophylaxis.
 [**Last Name 121**] PROBLEM - ENTER DESCRIPTION IN COMMENTS
   Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
   - not responsive to  pain today
   Very poor mental status at baseline, does not appear changed per
   [**Hospital1 630**] reports.  Progressive neurologic impairment as expected.
   - Consider head CT/LP for workup of fever as above, though does not
   appear that mental status worsening- will hold off for now.
   - Goals of care discussion with mother yesterday- would not want him
   intubated, would not want chest compressions- code status changed to
   DNR/DNI.

 ANEMIA, CHRONIC
   Macrocytic likely [**2-2**] HAART.  No change in last week.   Pt had Hct drop
   to 22.5 yesterday from 28.5 on admission.  Pt transfused 1 unit packed
   RBCs, Hct up to 24.8.
   -          Guiac stools
   -          Hct 24-25
   -                Continue to monitor Hct
   -
   # History of EtOH abuse.  Now at skilled nursing, no concern for
   withdrawal issues.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren 2.0 (Full) - [**2137-8-9**] 11:50 PM 40 mL/hour, added banana flakes
